Situation1: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story:
My phone buzzes twice in quick succession. First, a text from Jamie: “I can’t believe you’d say that. I thought you understood.” The words sting. I scroll up, rereading my last message, realizing how my rushed tone could have sounded cold. Jamie’s been my friend since college, and we’ve always promised to talk things out, never let misunderstandings fester. I know I should call her right now, explain, reassure her that I care.

But then my phone rings again. It’s the number I’ve been waiting for all week—a legislative aide for Senator Brooks. We’ve been fighting for this bill for months, and this is the window to make our case. The aide says she only has ten minutes. If I miss this, the chance might not come again. My heart pounds as I stare at my phone, torn between the urgent call of friendship and the rare opportunity to push for real change. Both matter deeply to me, and both demand my immediate attention. I can feel the pressure building, my loyalty to Jamie and my commitment to the cause pulling me in opposite directions.
